text: <@UL5AX4G2H> That's interesting for sure. I'd like to see more examples of how to communicate why those dependencies exist and what you could expect. I haven't seen a lot of examples so a good survey of the different ways of diagramming would be quite interesting

elements.text: That's interesting for sure. I'd like to see more examples of how to communicate why those dependencies exist and what you could expect. I haven't seen a lot of examples so a good survey of the different ways of diagramming would be quite interesting

text:
Are you looking to communicate why a dependency exists? I'd think using a directed graph to visualize dependencies and then having a reference from the edge to a long text blurb would be pretty good. So the graph might be A --> B to mean A depends on B, and then --> is clickable url to a new page with a description of why A depends on B

Do you mind elaborating on what you mean by "what you could expect"? An example would help me a lot

text:
I'm not exactly sure. I feel like I don't know what I don't know. I think it's about not knowing _what_ is possible to use as a notation for documentation. For example, I am working on an application right now that uses an Entity Component System to manage "business logic" and as such, there are multiple representations of the same data that are possible, the "Serialized model" which is shared with other systems, and the live model which lives within the component storages. What is a good way to document these different ways that we manage the same data? Similarly, some applications have a "Domain model", "Database model", and an "API Model" for the same concept like a "Delivery Route", do notations exist that can quickly communicate the relationship between the "Delivery Route" used in the database, versus in the Domain model, versus the API Model? I'm not sure...
I feel like it's an "unknown unknown"–Like I don't know that something exists, therefore I don't know how to look for it.

text: Maybe there isn't really anything out there that is that interesting.
